{{short description|Literary genre}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2022}} {{Globalize|article|United Kingdom|United States|Europe|date=June 2022}} [[File:Oscar Wilde MET DP136272.jpg|thumb|[[Oscar Wilde]], a gay writer of the 19th century who included allusions to homosexuality in works such as ''[[The Picture of Dorian Gray]]''. Wilde was jailed for homosexual relations in 1895.]] '''Gay literature''' is a collective term for [[literature]] produced by or for the [[gay community]] which involves [[character (arts)|character]]s, [[Plot (narrative)|plot]] lines, and/or themes portraying male [[homosexual]] behavior.<ref>{{cite book |title=A History of Gay Literature: The Male Tradition |publisher=Yale University Press |author = Gregory Woods |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofgaylite00wood|url-access=registration |isbn = 0-300-08088-3 |year = 1999 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Anthology of gay literature |publisher=Columbia University Press |author=Byrne R. S. Fone |url=https://archive.org/details/columbiaantholog00byrn |url-access=registration |quote=This anthology offers a chronological survey of writing that represents, interprets, and constructs the experience of love, friendship, intimacy, and desire between men over time--that is, what most readers would call gay male literature.|isbn=978-0-231-09670-6 |year=1998 }}</ref>
==Overview and history== Because the social acceptance of homosexuality has varied in many world cultures throughout history, LGBT literature has covered a vast array of themes and concepts. LGBT individuals have often turned to literature as a source of validation, understanding, and beautification of same-sex attraction. In contexts where homosexuality has been perceived negatively, LGBT literature may also document the psychological stresses and alienation suffered by those experiencing prejudice, legal discrimination, [[AIDS]], self-loathing, bullying, violence, religious condemnation, denial, suicide, persecution, and other such obstacles.
Themes of love between individuals of the same gender are found in a variety of ancient texts throughout the world. The ancient Greeks, in particular, explored the theme on a variety of different levels in such works as Plato's ''[[Symposium (Plato)|Symposium]]''.
=== Ancient mythology === [[File:Hyakinthos.jpg|thumb|[[Zephyrus]] and [[Hyacinth (mythology)|Hyakinthos]]: Greek myths often feature homosexuality and are a source for much modern speculative fiction. Mythic figures continue to appear in fantasy stories.<ref name="GLBTQ SciFi">{{cite web |first=Joseph |last=Marchesani |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/scifi_fantasy.html |title=Science Fiction and Fantasy |publisher=[[glbtq.com]] |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528020223/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/scifi_fantasy.html |archive-date=May 28, 2015 }}</ref>]] {{main|LGBT themes in mythology|LGBT themes in classical mythology}}
Many [[mythologies]] and religious narratives include stories of romantic affection or sexuality between men or feature divine actions that result in changes in gender. These myths have been interpreted as forms of LGBT expression and modern conceptions of sexuality and gender have been applied to them. Myths have been used by individual cultures, in part, to explain and validate their particular social institutions or to explain the cause of transgender identity or homosexuality.
[[LGBT themes in classical mythology|In classical mythology]], male lovers were attributed to ancient [[Greek god]]s and heroes such as [[Zeus]], [[Apollo]], [[Poseidon]] and [[Heracles]] (including [[Ganymede (mythology)|Ganymede]], [[Hyacinth (mythology)|Hyacinth]], [[Nerites (mythology)|Nerites]] and [[Hylas]], respectively) as a reflection and validation of the tradition of [[pederasty]].<ref name="GLBTQ Mythology">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/classical_myth.html|title=Classical Mythology|publisher=glbtq.com|access-date=February 5, 2015|last=Pequigney|first=Joseph|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415180456/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/classical_myth.html|archive-date=April 15, 2014}}</ref>
===Early works=== {{See also|Homoerotic literature in ancient Rome}} Though [[Homer]] did not explicitly portray the heroes [[Achilles and Patroclus]] as homosexual lovers in his 8th-century BC [[Trojan War]] epic, the ''[[Iliad]]'',<ref name= "Fox 2011">{{cite book |title=The Tribal Imagination: Civilization and the Savage Mind |last=Fox |first=Robin |year=2011 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |isbn=978-0-674-06094-4|page=223}}</ref><ref name="Martin 2012">{{cite book |title=Alexander the Great: the story of an ancient life |last=Martin |first=Thomas R. |year=2012 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-14844-3 |pages=99–100}}</ref> later ancient authors presented the intense relationship as such.<ref name="GLBTQ Achilles">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/classical_myth,5.html |title=Classical Mythology: Achilles, Patroclus, and the Love of Heroes |page=5 |date=2002 |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 5, 2015 |last=Pequigney |first=Joseph |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141202015904/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/classical_myth,5.html |archive-date=December 2, 2014 }}</ref> In his 5th-century BC lost tragedy ''[[The Myrmidons]]'', [[Aeschylus]] casts Achilles and Patroclus as pederastic lovers. In a surviving fragment of the play, Achilles speaks of "our frequent kisses" and a "devout union of the thighs".<ref name="GLBTQ Achilles"/><ref>[[Aeschylus]]. ''[[The Myrmidons]]''. Fr. 135. Radt, Stefan.</ref> [[Plato]] does the same in his ''[[Symposium (Plato)|Symposium]]'' (385–370 BC); the speaker [[Phaedrus (Athenian)|Phaedrus]] cites Aeschylus and holds Achilles up as an example of how people will be more brave and even sacrifice themselves for their lovers.<ref name="GLBTQ Achilles"/><ref name="GLBTQ Plato 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/plato,2.html |title=Plato (427-327 B.C.E.): The ''Symposium'' |page=2 |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 5, 2015 |last=Crompton |first=Louis |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206020136/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/plato,2.html |archive-date=February 6, 2015 }}</ref> In his oration ''[[Against Timarchus]]'', [[Aeschines]] argues that though Homer "hides their love and avoids giving a name to their friendship", Homer assumed that educated readers would understand the "exceeding greatness of their affection".<ref>{{cite book |title=Achilles in Greek Tragedy |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |last=Michelakis |first=Pantelis |year=2007 |page=51 |isbn=978-0-521-81843-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0002%3Aspeech%3D1%3Asection%3D142 |author=Aeschines |publisher=[[Perseus Project]] |title= ''Against Timarchus'' |access-date=February 5, 2015|author-link=Aeschines }}</ref> Plato's ''Symposium'' also includes a [[creation myth]] that explains homo- and heterosexuality ([[Aristophanes]] speech) and celebrates the pederastic tradition and erotic love between men ([[Pausanias of Athens|Pausanias]] speech), as does another of his [[dialogue]]s, ''[[Phaedrus (dialogue)|Phaedrus]]''.<ref name="GLBTQ Plato 2"/><ref name="GLBTQ Plato 3">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/plato,3.html |title=Plato (427-327 B.C.E.): The ''Phaedrus'' |page=3 |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 5, 2015 |last=Crompton |first=Louis |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206010046/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/plato,3.html |archive-date=February 6, 2015 }}</ref>
The tradition of [[pederasty in ancient Greece]] (as early as 650 BC) and later the acceptance of limited [[homosexuality in ancient Rome]] infused an awareness of male-male attraction and sex into ancient poetry. In the [[s:Eclogues/Eclogue II|second]] of [[Virgil]]'s ''[[Eclogues]]'' (1st century BC), the shepherd [[Corydon (character)|Corydon]] proclaims his love for the boy Alexis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/230/230-h/230-h.htm#book02 |title=''Eclogues II'' |author=Virgil |publisher=[[Project Gutenberg]] |access-date=February 4, 2015|author-link=Virgil }}</ref> Some of the erotic poetry of [[Catullus]] in the same century is directed at other men (''Carmen 48'', ''50'', and ''99''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudy.negenborn.net/catullus/text2/e48.htm|title=Gaius Valerius Catullus: ''Carmen 48'' (English)|access-date=February 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudy.negenborn.net/catullus/text2/e50.htm|title=Gaius Valerius Catullus: ''Carmen 50'' (English)|access-date=February 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudy.negenborn.net/catullus/text2/e99.htm|title=Gaius Valerius Catullus: ''Carmen 99'' (English)|access-date=February 4, 2015}}</ref> and in a [[epithalamium|wedding hymn]] (''Carmen 61'') he portrays a male [[concubine]] about to be supplanted by his master's future wife.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudy.negenborn.net/catullus/text2/e61.htm |title=Gaius Valerius Catullus: ''Carmen 61'' (English) |publisher=Lines 119–143 |access-date=February 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=James L. |last=Butrica |chapter=Some Myths and Anomalies in the Study of Roman Sexuality |title=Same-Sex Desire and Love in Greco-Roman Antiquity |date=2006 |pages=218, 224}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Amy |last=Richlin |title=Not before Homosexuality: The Materiality of the ''cinaedus'' and the Roman Law against Love between Men |journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality |volume=3|issue=4 |date=1993 |page=534|jstor=3704392}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Ronnie |last=Ancona |chapter=(Un)Constrained Male Desire: An Intertextual Reading of Horace ''Odes'' 2.8 and Catullus Poem 61 |title=Gendered Dynamics in Latin Love Poetry |publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University Press]] |date=2005 |page=47}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Mark |last=Petrini |title=The Child and the Hero: Coming of Age in Catullus and Vergil |publisher=[[University of Michigan Press]] |date=1997 |pages=19–20}}</ref> The first line of his infamous [[invective]] ''[[Carmen 16]]'' — which has been called "one of the filthiest expressions ever written in Latin—or in any other language, for that matter" — contains explicit homosexual sex acts.<ref>{{cite web |first=Harry |last=Mount |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/6649756/Mark-Lowe-is-right-The-Romans-said-it-better.html |title=Mark Lowe is right: The Romans said it better |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=November 25, 2009 |access-date=February 4, 2015}}</ref>
The ''[[Satyricon]]'' by [[Petronius]] is a Latin work of fiction detailing the misadventures of Encolpius and his lover, a handsome and promiscuous sixteen-year-old servant boy named Giton. Written in the 1st century AD during the reign of [[Nero]], it is the earliest known text of its kind depicting homosexuality.<ref name="GLBTQ Petronius">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/petronius.html |title=Petronius (ca 27-66) |first=Raymond-Jean |last=Frontain |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218155848/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/petronius.html |archive-date=December 18, 2014 }}</ref>
In the celebrated Japanese work ''[[The Tale of Genji]]'', written by [[Murasaki Shikibu]] in the early 11th century,<ref>{{Cite book |title=The Tale of Genji |first=Murasaki |last=Shikibu |author-link=Murasaki Shikibu |translator-first=Royall |translator-last=Tyler |publisher=[[Penguin Classics]]|year=2002 |isbn=0-14-243714-X |pages=i–ii, xii, xxvi|title-link=The Tale of Genji }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Ivan |last=Morris |title=The World of the Shining Prince |url=https://archive.org/details/worldofshining00morr |url-access=registration |date=1964 |page=[https://archive.org/details/worldofshining00morr/page/277 277]|publisher=New York, Knopf }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Bryan |first=J. Ingram |title=The Literature of Japan |date=1930 |publisher=[[Henry Holt and Company]] |location=New York |page=65}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |title=Introduction to Classic Japanese Literature |editor-first=Kokusai Bunka |editor-last=Shinkokai|date=1970 |publisher=Greenwood Printing |isbn= 0-8371-3118-9 |page=37}}</ref> the title character [[Hikaru Genji]] is rejected by the lady [[Utsusemi]] in chapter 3 and instead sleeps with her young brother: "Genji pulled the boy down beside him ... Genji, for his part, or so one is informed, found the boy more attractive than his chilly sister."<ref>{{cite book |first=Murasaki |last=Shikibu |title=The Tale of Genji |translator-first=Edward G. |translator-last=Seidensticker |translator-link=Edward Seidensticker |page=48 |date=1976 |publisher=Turtle Publishing |isbn=978-4-8053-0919-3}}</ref>
[[Antonio Rocco]]'s ''[[Alcibiades the Schoolboy]]'', published anonymously in 1652, is an Italian [[dialogue]] written as a defense of homosexual [[sodomy]]. The first such explicit work known to be written since ancient times, its intended purpose as a "[[Carnivalesque]] [[satire]]", a defense of [[pederasty]], or a work of [[pornography]] is unknown, and debated.<ref name="GLBTQ Rocco">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/rocco_a.html |title=Rocco, Antonio (1586-1653) |first=Hubert |last=Kennedy |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218160254/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/rocco_a.html |archive-date=December 18, 2014 }}</ref>
Several [[medieval]] European works contain references to homosexuality, such as in ''[[Giovanni Boccaccio]]''{{'}}s ''[[Decameron]]'' or ''[[Lanval]]'', a French [[lai (poetic form)|lai]], in which the knight Lanval is accused by [[Guinevere]] of having "no desire for women".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Juraisinski|first=Stefan|title=Treason and the Charge of Sodomy in the ''Lai de Lanval''|journal=Romance Quarterly|date=2007|pages=290–302|doi=10.3200/RQTR.54.4.290-302|volume=54|issue=4|s2cid=159712739}}</ref> Others include homosexual themes, like ''[[Yde et Olive]]''.<ref>Amer, Sahar. ''Crossing Borders: Love between Women in Medieval French and Arabic Literatures''. Philadelphia, University of Pennsylvania Press (The Middle Ages Series). 2008, xii + 252 p.</ref><ref>Clark, Robert. "A heroine's sexual itinerary: incest, transvestism, and same-sex marriage in ''Yde and Olive'' ". ''Gender Transgressions: Crossing the Normative Barrier in Old French Literature''. Karen J. Taylor (ed.). New York, Garland (Garland Reference Library of the Humanities, 2064). 1998, p. 89-105.</ref>
=== 18th and 19th centuries === The era known as the [[Age of Enlightenment]] (the 1650s to the 1780s) gave rise to, in part, a general challenge to the traditional doctrines of society in Western Europe. A particular interest in the Classical era of Greece and Rome "as a model for contemporary life" put the Greek appreciation of nudity, the male form and male friendship (and the inevitable homoerotic overtones) into art and literature.<ref name="GLBTQ Enlightenment">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/social-sciences/europe_enlightenment.html |title=Europe: The Enlightenment |first=John D. |last=Stanley |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131021736/http://www.glbtq.com/social-sciences/europe_enlightenment.html |archive-date=January 31, 2015 }}</ref> It was common for gay authors at this time to include allusions to Greek mythological characters as a code that homosexual readers would recognize.<ref name="HP 2014-05">{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/trebor-healey/early-gay-literature-redi_b_5373869.html |title=Early Gay Literature Rediscovered |first=Trebor |last=Healey |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=May 28, 2014 |access-date=May 31, 2014}}</ref> Gay men of the period "commonly understood ancient Greece and Rome to be societies where homosexual relationships were tolerated and even encouraged", and references to those cultures might identify an author or book's sympathy with gay readers and gay themes but probably be overlooked by straight readers.<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> Despite the "increased visibility of queer behavior" and prospering networks of male prostitution in cities like Paris and London, homosexual activity had been outlawed in England (and by extension, the United States) as early as the [[Buggery Act 1533]]. Across much of Europe in the 1700s and 1800s, the legal punishment for sodomy was death, making it dangerous to publish or distribute anything with overt gay themes.<ref name="GLBTQ Enlightenment"/><ref name="HP 2014-05"/> James Jenkins of [[Valancourt Books]] noted: {{Blockquote|These sorts of coded, subtextual ways of writing about homosexuality were often necessary, since up until the 1950s British authors could be prosecuted for writing openly about homosexuality, and in the U.S., authors and publishers could also face legal action and suppression of their books, not to mention social or moral condemnation that might end an author's career.<ref name="HP 2014-05"/>|author=|title=|source=}}
Many early [[Gothic fiction]] authors, like [[Matthew Lewis (writer)|Matthew Lewis]], [[William Thomas Beckford]] and [[Francis Lathom]], were homosexual, and would sublimate these themes and express them in more acceptable forms, using transgressive genres like Gothic and horror fiction.<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> The title character of Lewis's ''[[The Monk]]'' (1796) falls in love with young novice Rosario, and though Rosario is later revealed to be a woman named Matilda, the gay subtext is clear.<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> A similar situation occurs in [[Charles Maturin]]'s ''The Fatal Revenge'' (1807) when the valet Cyprian asks his master, Ippolito, to kiss him as though he were Ippolito's lover; later Cyprian is also revealed to be a woman. In Maturin's ''[[Melmoth the Wanderer]]'' (1820), the close friendship between a young monk and a new novice is scrutinized as potentially "too like love". [[Sheridan Le Fanu]]'s novella ''[[Carmilla]]'' (1872) was the first [[lesbian vampire]] story,<ref name="Garber">{{cite book |last=Garber |first=Eric |author2= Lyn Paleo |title=Uranian Worlds: A Guide to Alternative Sexuality in Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Horror |url=https://archive.org/details/uranianworldsgui0000garb |url-access=registration |chapter=''Carmilla'' |publisher=[[G. K. Hall]]|year=1983 |isbn=978-0-8161-1832-8 |page=[https://archive.org/details/uranianworldsgui0000garb/page/76 76]}}</ref><ref name="Carmilla 1">{{cite book |chapter=Carmilla |title=In a Glass Darkly|last=LeFanu |first=J[oseph] Sheridan |author-link=Sheridan le Fanu |location=London |publisher=R. Bentley & Son |year=1872|title-link=In a Glass Darkly}}</ref><ref name="Carmilla 2">{{cite book |last=LeFanu |first=J[oseph] Sheridan |chapter=Carmilla |title=Daughters of Darkness: Lesbian Vampire Stories |url=https://archive.org/details/daughtersofdarkn00kees |url-access=registration |editor=Pam Keesey |location=Pittsburgh, PA |publisher=Cleis Press |year=1993}}</ref> and influenced [[Bram Stoker]]'s ''[[Dracula]]'' (1897).<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> Stoker's novel has its own homoerotic aspects, as when [[Count Dracula]] warns off the female [[vampire]]s and claims [[Jonathan Harker]], saying "This man belongs to me!"<ref name="HP 2014-05"/>
''[[A Year in Arcadia: Kyllenion]]'' (1805) by [[Augustus, Duke of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg]] is "the earliest known novel that centers on an explicitly male-male love affair".<ref name="Taggerty 612">{{cite book |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JwB5AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA612 |title=Encyclopedia of Lesbian and Gay Histories and Cultures |editor1-first=George |editor1-last=Haggerty |editor2-first=Bonnie |editor2-last=Zimmerman |year=2000 |chapter=German Literature |page=612 |publisher=Garland Science |isbn=0-815-34055-9 }}</ref> Set in ancient Greece, the German novel features several couples—including a homosexual one—falling in love, overcoming obstacles and living happily ever after. The [[Romantic movement]] gaining momentum at the end of the 18th century allowed men to "express deep affection for each other", and the motif of ancient Greece as "a utopia of male-male love" was an acceptable vehicle to reflect this, but some of Duke August's contemporaries felt that his characters "stepped over the bounds of manly affection into unseemly eroticism."<ref name="GLBTQ German">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/german_austrian_lit2_19c_20c.html |title=German and Austrian Literature: Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries |first=James W. |last=Jones |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007093949/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/german_austrian_lit2_19c_20c.html |archive-date=October 7, 2014 }}</ref> The first American gay novel was ''[[Joseph and His Friend: A Story of Pennsylvania]]'' (1870) by [[Bayard Taylor]], the story of a newly engaged young man who finds himself instead falling in love with another man.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Whitcomb |first1=Selden L.|last2=Matthews |first2=Brander |title=Chronological Outlines of American Literature |publisher=Norwood Press |date=1893 |page=186}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Playing the Game: The Homosexual Novel in America |last=Austen |first=Roger |publisher=[[Bobbs-Merrill Company]] |location=Indianapolis |year=1977 |page=[https://archive.org/details/playinggamehomos00aust/page/9 9] |isbn=978-0-672-52287-1 |url=https://archive.org/details/playinggamehomos00aust/page/9 }}</ref> Robert K. Martin called it "quite explicit in its adoption of a political stance toward homosexuality" and notes that the character Philip "argues for the 'rights' of those 'who cannot shape themselves according to the common-place pattern of society.{{'"}}<ref name="GLBTQ American 19th">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/am_lit6_19c,2.html |title=American Literature: Nineteenth Century |first=Robert K. |last=Martin |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204041456/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/am_lit6_19c,2.html |archive-date=February 4, 2015 }}</ref> [[Henry Blake Fuller]]'s 1898 play, ''At St. Judas's'', and 1919 novel, ''[[Bertram Cope's Year]]'', are noted as among the earliest published American works in literature on the theme of homosexual relationships.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://chicagoliteraryhof.org/inductees/profile/henry-blake-fuller |title=Henry Blake Fuller |website=Chicago Literary Hall of Fame |access-date=March 31, 2019}}</ref>
The new "atmosphere of frankness" created by the Enlightenment sparked the production of pornography like [[John Cleland]]'s infamous ''[[Fanny Hill]]'' (1749), which features a rare graphic scene of male homosexual sex.<ref name="GLBTQ Enlightenment"/><ref name="GLBTQ Cleland">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/cleland_j.html |title=Cleland, John (1709-1789) |first=Terrence |last=Johnson |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202073924/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/cleland_j.html |archive-date=February 2, 2015 }}</ref> Published anonymously a century later, ''[[The Sins of the Cities of the Plain]]'' (1881) and ''[[Teleny, or The Reverse of the Medal]]'' (1893) are two of the earliest pieces of English-language pornography to explicitly and near-exclusively concern homosexuality. ''The Sins of the Cities of the Plain'' is about a male prostitute, and set in London around the time of the [[Cleveland Street Scandal]] and the [[Oscar Wilde]] trials.<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> ''Teleny'', chronicling a passionate affair between a Frenchman and a Hungarian pianist, is often attributed to a collaborative effort by Wilde and some of his contemporaries.<ref name=nelson>{{cite book |last=Nelson |first=James |title=Publisher to the Decadents: Leonard Smithers in the Careers of Beardsley, Wilde, Dowson |location=Philadelphia |publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press |year=2000}}</ref><ref name=graykeep>{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Gray |author2= Christopher Keep |chapter=An Uninterrupted Current: Homoeroticism and collaborative authorship in ''Teleny'' |editor1=Marjorie Stone |editor2=Judith Thompson |title=Literary Couplings: Writing Couples, Collaborators, and the Construction of Authorship |publisher=University of Wisconsin Press |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-299-21764-8 |page=193}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Edouard |last=Roditi |title=Oscar Wilde |publisher=New Directions Publishing |year=1986 |isbn=0-8112-0995-4 |page=[https://archive.org/details/oscarwilde00rodi_gw4/page/168 168] |url=https://archive.org/details/oscarwilde00rodi_gw4/page/168 }}</ref> Wilde's more mainstream ''[[The Picture of Dorian Gray]]'' (1890) still shocked readers with its sensuality and overtly homosexual characters.<ref name="Garber & Paleo 1983 148">{{cite book |author=Garber & Paleo |title=Uranian Worlds |chapter=''The Picture of Dorian Gray''|year=1983|page=148}}</ref> Drew Banks called Dorian Gray a groundbreaking gay character because he was "one of the first in a long list of [[hedonism|hedonistic]] fellows whose homosexual tendencies secured a terrible fate."<ref name="Meloy">{{cite web |url=http://www.afterelton.com/print/2007/9/groundbreakinggaycharacters |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831180332/http://www.afterelton.com/print/2007/9/groundbreakinggaycharacters |title=Influential Gay Characters in Literature |first=Kilian |last=Meloy |date=September 24, 2007 |access-date=June 17, 2014 |archive-date=August 31, 2010 |publisher=[[AfterElton.com]] }}</ref> The French realist [[Émile Zola]] in his novel ''[[Nana (novel)|Nana]]'' (1880) depicted, along with a wide variety of heterosexual couplings and some lesbian scenes, a single homosexual character, Labordette. Paris theater society and the ''demi-monde'' are long accustomed to his presence and role as go-between; he knows all the women, escorts them, and runs errands for them. He is "a parasite, with even a touch of pimp", but also a more sympathetic figure than most of the men, as much a moral coward as them but physically brave and not a stereotype.<ref>{{cite book|first=Émile|last=Zola|contribution=Introduction|pages=xix–xx|title=Nana|contributor-first=Douglass |contributor-last=Parmée |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1992}}</ref>{{efn|In chapter XXI of his 1912 novel ''[[The Gods Are Athirst]]'', Zola depicts a brief failed attempt at a same-sex liaison. Julie has been wearing men's clothing to avoid being recognized. A middle-aged man who has on occasion followed her invites her to share his umbrella. Startled by her voice when she accepts, he runs away. "She suddenly understood, and despite her worries could not prevent herself from smiling."}}
=== 20th century === {{see also|List of gay novels prior to the Stonewall riots}} By the 20th century, discussion of homosexuality became more open and society's understanding of it evolved. A number of novels with explicitly gay themes and characters began to appear in the domain of mainstream or art literature.
[[Nobel Prize]]-winner [[André Gide]]'s semi-autobiographical novel ''[[The Immoralist]]'' (1902) finds a newly married man reawakened by his attraction to a series of young Arab boys.<ref name="GLBTQ Gide 2">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/gide_a,2.html |title=Gide, André (1869-1951) - Page 2 |first=Scott |last=Fish |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 4, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205001837/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/gide_a%2C2.html |archive-date=February 5, 2015 }}</ref> Though Bayard Taylor's ''Joseph and His Friend'' (1870) had been the first American gay novel, [[Edward Prime-Stevenson]]'s ''[[Imre: A Memorandum]]'' (1906) was the first in which the homosexual couple were happy and united at the end. Initially published privately under the pseudonym "Xavier Mayne", it tells the story of a British aristocrat and a Hungarian soldier whose new friendship turns into love.<ref name="GLBTQ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205000415/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/gide_a,3.html |archive-date=February 5, 2015 }}</ref>
British author [[E.M. Forster]] earned a prominent reputation as a novelist while concealing his own homosexuality from the broader British public. In 1913–14, he privately penned ''[[Maurice (novel)|Maurice]]'', a bildungsroman that follows a young, upper-middle-class man through the self-discovery of his own attraction to other men, two relationships, and his interactions with an often uncomprehending or hostile society. The book is notable for its affirming tone and happy ending. "A happy ending was imperative", wrote Forster, "I was determined that in fiction anyway, two men should fall in love and remain in it for the ever and ever that fiction allows ... Happiness is its keynote."<ref>{{cite book|last=Forster|first=Edward Morgan|title=Maurice|year=1971|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-393-31032-9}}</ref> The book was not published until 1971, after Forster's death.<ref name="GLBTQ Modernism"/> [[William J. Mann]] said of the novel, "[Alec Scudder of ''Maurice'' was] a refreshingly unapologetic young gay man who was not an effete Oscar Wilde aristocrat, but rather a working class, masculine, ordinary guy ... an example of the working class teaching the privileged class about honesty and authenticity {{mdash}} a bit of a stereotype now, but back then quite extraordinary."<ref name="Meloy"/>
In Germany in 1920, [[Erwin von Busse]] published a collection of short stories about erotic encounters between men using the pseudonym Granand. Promptly banned for "indecency", it was not republished until 1993 and only appeared in an English translation as ''Berlin Garden of Erotic Delights'' in 2022.<ref>{{cite book | author = Granand |contributor= [[:de:Manfred Herzer|Manfred Herzer]] | contribution = Afterword |date= 2022 |title= Berlin Garden of Erotic Delights |publisher= Warbler Press |pages= 79–84 }}</ref>
[[Blair Niles]]'s ''[[Strange Brother]]'' (1931), about the platonic relationship between a heterosexual woman and a gay man in [[New York City]] in the late 1920s and early 1930s, is an early, objective exploration of homosexual issues during the [[Harlem Renaissance]].<ref name="Stryker 97">{{cite book |author-link=Susan Stryker |last=Stryker |first=Susan |title=Queer Pulp: Perverted Passions from the Golden Age of the Paperback |location=San Francisco, CA |publisher=Chronicle Books |year=2001 |page=97}}</ref> Though praised for its journalistic approach, sympathetic nature and promotion of tolerance and compassion,<ref name="Stryker 100">{{cite book |last=Stryker |title=Queer Pulp |year=2001 |page=100}}</ref><ref name="Sarotte">{{cite book |last=Sarotte |first=Georges-Michel |title=Like a Brother: Male Homosexuality in the American Novel and Theatre from Herman Melville to James Baldwin |location=Garden City, NY |publisher=Anchor Press |year=1978 |page=18}}</ref> the novel has been numbered among a group of early gay novels that is "cast in the form of a tragic melodrama"<ref name="Young">{{cite book |last=Young |first=Ian |title=The Male Homosexual in Literature: A Bibliography |location=Metuchen, NJ |publisher=The Scarecrow Press |year=1975 |pages=153–154}}</ref> and, according to editor and author [[Anthony Slide]], illustrates the "basic assumption that gay characters in literature must come to a tragic end."<ref name="Slide1">{{cite book |last=Slide |first=Anthony |author-link=Anthony Slide |title=Lost Gay Novels: A Reference Guide to Fifty Works from the First Half of the Twentieth Century |publisher=[[Routledge]] |year=2003 |pages=1–2|title-link=Lost Gay Novels|doi=10.4324/9780203057230 |isbn=978-1-136-57208-1 }}</ref> "Smoke, Lilies, and Jade" by gay author and artist [[Richard Bruce Nugent]], published in 1926, was the first short story by an African-American writer openly addressing his homosexuality. Written in a modernist stream-of-consciousness style, its subject matter was bisexuality and interracial male desire.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nero |first1=Charles I. |title=''Gay Rebel of the Harlem Renaissance: Selections from the Work of Richard Bruce Nugent '' |journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality |date=2003 |volume=12 |issue=4 |pages=672–676 |doi=10.1353/sex.2004.0034|department=[Review]|jstor=3704681|s2cid=162087245 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lostgayfiction.wordpress.com/2012/03/30/smoke-lilies-and-jade-by-richard-bruce-nugent/|title='Smoke, Lilies and Jade' by Richard Bruce Nugent|date=March 30, 2012|website=Lost Gay Fiction|access-date=May 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://userpage.fu-berlin.de/~wilker/harlem/smokelilies.htm|title=''Smoke, Lilies and Jade''|website=userpage.fu-berlin.de|access-date=May 15, 2018}}</ref>
[[Forman Brown]]'s 1933 novel ''[[Better Angel]]'', published under the pseudonym Richard Meeker,<ref name="Slide128">{{cite book |last=Slide|title=Lost Gay Novels|chapter=Richard Meeker, ''Better Angel''|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6Dj1cA_vkV4C&pg=PA128|year=2003|page=128|publisher=Psychology Press |isbn=978-1-56023-414-2}}</ref> is an early novel which describes a gay lifestyle without condemning it.<ref name="Slide127">{{cite book |last=Slide|title=Lost Gay Novels|chapter=Richard Meeker, ''Better Angel''|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6Dj1cA_vkV4C&pg=PA127|year=2003|page=127|publisher=Psychology Press |isbn=978-1-56023-414-2}}</ref> Christopher Carey called it "the first homosexual novel with a truly happy ending".<ref name="Carey">{{cite book|last=Carey|first=Christopher|title=Trials from Classical Athens|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|page=484}}</ref> Slide names only four familiar gay novels of the first half of the 20th century in English: [[Djuna Barnes]]' ''[[Nightwood]]'' (1936), [[Carson McCullers]]' ''[[Reflections in a Golden Eye (novel)|Reflections in a Golden Eye]]'' (1941), [[Truman Capote]]'s ''[[Other Voices, Other Rooms (novel)|Other Voices, Other Rooms]]'' (1948) and [[Gore Vidal]]'s ''[[The City and the Pillar]]'' (1948).<ref name="Slide1"/> In [[John O'Hara]]'s 1935 novel ''[[BUtterfield 8 (novel)|BUtterfield 8]]'', the principal female character Gloria Wondrous has a friend Ann Paul, who in school "was suspect because of a couple of crushes which ... her former schoolmates were too free about calling Lesbian, and Gloria did not think so". Gloria speculates that "there was a little of that in practically all women", considers her own experience with women making passes, and rejects her own theory.<ref>{{cite book |first=John |last= O'Hara | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=S2TOQC-k0foC&pg=PT116| pages=186, 199| title = BUtterfield 8 | date= 2013|publisher=Penguin|access-date = March 28, 2019 |isbn= 978-1-101-60296-6 }}</ref>
The story of a young man who is [[coming of age]] and discovers his own homosexuality,<ref>{{cite book |last=Austen |first=Roger |title=Playing the Game: The Homosexual Novel in America |url=https://archive.org/details/playinggamehomos00aust |url-access=registration |location=New York |publisher=Bobbs-Merrill Company, Inc.|year=1977|page=[https://archive.org/details/playinggamehomos00aust/page/119 119]}}</ref> ''The City and the Pillar'' (1946) is recognized as the first [[Post-war|post-World War II]] novel whose openly gay and well-adjusted protagonist is not killed off at the end of the story for defying [[Norm (sociology)|social norms]]. It is also one of the "definitive [[war novel|war-influenced]] gay novels", one of the few books of its period dealing directly with male homosexuality.<ref name="Stryker 17-103">{{cite book |last=Stryker |title=Queer Pulp |year=2001 |pages=17, 103}}</ref><ref name="Bronski 343">{{cite book |last=Bronski |first=Michael |author-link=Michael Bronski |title=Pulp Friction: Uncovering the Golden Age of Gay Male Pulps|url=https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780312252670 |url-access=registration |location=New York |publisher=[[St. Martin's Griffin]] |date=2003|page=[https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780312252670/page/343 343]|isbn=978-0-312-25267-0 }}</ref> ''The City and the Pillar'' has also been called "the most notorious of the gay novels of the 1940s and 1950s."<ref>{{cite book |editor=Drewey Wayne Gunn |title=The Golden Age of Gay Fiction |location=Albion, New York |publisher=MLR Press |year=2003 |page=3 (Ian Young)}}</ref> It sparked a public scandal, including notoriety and criticism, because it was released at a time when homosexuality was commonly considered immoral and because it was the first book by an accepted American author to portray overt homosexuality as a natural behavior.<ref name="Bronski 343"/> Upon its release, ''[[The New York Times]]'' refused to publish advertisements for the novel and Vidal was [[blacklist]]ed to the extent that no major newspaper or magazine would review any of his novels for six years.<ref>{{cite book |last=Vidal |year=1995 |title=The City and the Pillar and Seven Early Stories |page=xvi}}</ref> Modern scholars note the importance of the novel to the visibility of gay literature. [[Michael Bronski]] points out that "gay-male-themed books received greater critical attention than lesbian ones" and that "writers such as Gore Vidal were accepted as important American writers, even when they received attacks from homophobic critics."<ref name="Bronski 5">{{cite book |last=Bronksi|title=Pulp Friction |year=2003 |page=5}}</ref> [[Ian Young (writer)|Ian Young]] notes that social disruptions of World War II changed public morals, and lists ''The City and the Pillar'' among a spate of war novels that use the military as backdrop for overt homosexual behavior.<ref name="Young"/>

In Taiwan, during the [[Martial law in Taiwan|martial law period]] (1949–1987), the [[Kuomintang]] government focused on strengthening Taiwan's industrial and economic power and reinforcing traditional Confucious values on society.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=SHI |first=Flair Donglai |date=2017 |title=Coming out of History and Coming Home: Homosexual Identification in Pai Hsien-yung's: "Crystal Boys" |journal=Chinese Literature: Essays, Articles, Reviews (CLEAR) |volume=39 |pages=135–152 |jstor=45014214 |issn=0161-9705}}</ref> The heterosexual image of the modern family dominated, and "public discourses of same-sex desire were almost non-existent."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Damm |first=Jens |date=2005 |title=Same Sex Desire and Society in Taiwan, 1970–1987 |journal=The China Quarterly |volume=181 |issue=181 |pages=67–81 |doi=10.1017/S0305741005000044 |jstor=20192444 |s2cid=154473654 |issn=0305-7410}}</ref> Nevertheless, [[Pai Hsien-yung]]'s [[Jade Love (novella)|''Jade Love'']] (1960), "Moon Dream" (1960), "Youthfulness" (1961), and "Seventeen Years Old and Lonely" (1961) — novellas and short stories exploring male homosexual desire — were published in ''[[Xiandai Wenxue]]''. He published "[[Taipei People#A Sky Full of Bright, Twinkling Stars (滿天裏亮晶晶的星星)|A Sky Full of Bright, Twinkling Stars]]" in 1969, which follows gay characters who frequent Taipei's New Park area and would appear in Pai's 1983 novel ''[[Crystal Boys]]''. ''Crystal Boys'' is set in 1970s Taipei and covers the main character Li-Qing's life after he is expelled from school for engaging in sexual relations with his classmate Zhao Ying.<ref>{{Citation |title=Plural not singular: homosexuality in Taiwanese literature of the 1960s TA WEI CHI |date=2016-12-19 |work=Perverse Taiwan |pages=48–51 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9781315394022-9 |isbn=978-1-315-39402-2 }}</ref> It is commonly identified as "the first Chinese novel that depicts the life struggles in the homosexual community [and] grew out of the particular socio-historical environment of Taiwan in the 1970s."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=SHI |first=Flair Donglai |date=2017 |title=Coming out of History and Coming Home: Homosexual Identification in Pai Hsien-yung's: "Crystal Boys" |journal=Chinese Literature: Essays, Articles, Reviews (CLEAR) |volume=39 |page=151 |jstor=45014214 |issn=0161-9705}}</ref>
Other works published in Taiwan in the early 1960s include [[Chiang Kuei]]'s ''Double Suns'' (1961), with depictions of male homosexual desire, and [[Kuo Liang-hui]]'s ''Green Is the Grass'' (1963), which follows two Taiwanese middle school boys who exhibit sexual and romantic desires toward each other.<ref>{{Citation |title=Plural not singular: homosexuality in Taiwanese literature of the 1960s T A WEI CHI |date=2016-12-19 |work=Perverse Taiwan |pages=51–54 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9781315394022-9 |isbn=978-1-315-39402-2 }}</ref> The status of ''Double Suns'' in the Taiwanese gay literature scene has been questioned since male homosexuality is not the main focus of the work. On this, [[Chi Ta-wei]] comments on its influence and significance in the history of homosexual literature in Taiwan, writing that "[t]o underestimate [the characters of Double Suns] and deem them 'not homosexual enough' is to truncate the history of literature and to regulate the ever-elusive homosexuality to a confined definition."<ref>{{Citation |title=Plural not singular: homosexuality in Taiwanese literature of the 1960s T A WEI CHI |date=2016-12-19 |work=Perverse Taiwan |page=53 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9781315394022-9 |isbn=978-1-315-39402-2 }}</ref>
James Baldwin followed ''Giovanni's Room'' with ''[[Another Country (novel)|Another Country]]'' (1962), a "controversial bestseller" that "explicitly combines racial and sexual protests ... structured around the lives of eight racially, regionally, socioeconomically, and sexually diverse characters."<ref name="GLBTQ Baldwin"/> [[John Rechy]]'s ''[[City of Night]]'' (1963) and ''[[Numbers (novel)|Numbers]]'' (1967) are graphic tales of [[male hustler]]s; ''City of Night'' has been called a "landmark novel" that "marked a radical departure from all other novels of its kind, and gave voice to a subculture that had never before been revealed with such acuity."<ref name="GLBTQ Rechy">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/rechy_j.html |title=Rechy, John (b. 1934) |first=Gregory W. |last=Bredbeck |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206200254/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/rechy_j.html |archive-date=February 6, 2015 }}</ref><ref name="GLBTQ CoN 50">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/blogs/john_rechys_city_of_night_at_.html |title=John Rechy's ''City of Night'' at 50 |first=Claude J. |last=Summers |publisher=glbtq.com |date=October 25, 2013 |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206190742/http://www.glbtq.com/blogs/john_rechys_city_of_night_at_.html |archive-date=February 6, 2015 }}</ref> [[Claude J. Summers]] wrote of [[Christopher Isherwood]]'s ''[[A Single Man (novel)|A Single Man]]'' (1964): {{Blockquote|''A Single Man'' more fully develops the context of gay oppression than do [Isherwood's] earlier novels ... To portray homosexuals as simply another tribe in a nation comprising many different tribes is both to soften the stigma linked to homosexuality and to encourage solidarity among gay people. And by associating the mistreatment of homosexuals with the discrimination suffered by other minorities in America, Isherwood legitimizes the grievances of gay people at a time when homosexuals were not recognized either as a genuine minority or as valuable members of the human community. Presaging the gay liberation movement, ''A Single Man'' presents homosexuality as simply a human variation that should be accorded value and respect and depicts homosexuals as a group whose grievances should be redressed.<ref name="GLBTQ Isherwood 3">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/isherwood_c,3.html |title=Isherwood, Christopher (1904-1986): Isherwood's Masterpiece, ''A Single Man'' |first=Claude J. |last=Summers |page=3 |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206190619/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/isherwood_c,3.html |archive-date=February 6, 2015 }}</ref>}}
[[George Baxt]]'s ''A Queer Kind of Death'' (1966) introduced Pharaoh Love, the first gay black detective in fiction. The novel was met with considerable acclaim, and ''The New York Times'' critic [[Anthony Boucher]] wrote, "This is a detective story, and unlike any other that you have read. No brief review can attempt to convey its quality. I merely note that it deals with a Manhattan subculture wholly devoid of ethics or morality, that said readers may well find it 'shocking', that it is beautifully plotted and written with elegance and wit ... and that you must under no circumstances miss it."<ref name="NYT 1966">{{cite journal |first=Anthony |last=Boucher |author-link=Anthony Boucher |journal=The New York Times |title=Criminals At Large |date=June 5, 1966 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0DE3D91231E53ABC4D53DFB066838D679EDE |access-date=June 28, 2014}}</ref> Love would be the central figure in two immediate sequels ''Swing Low Sweet Harriet'' (1967) and ''Topsy and Evil'' (1968) and also two later novels, ''A Queer Kind of Love'' (1994) and ''A Queer Kind of Umbrella'' (1995). In his controversial 1968 [[satire]] ''[[Myra Breckinridge]]'', Gore Vidal explored the mutability of gender-roles and sexual-orientation as being social constructs established by [[social mores]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Kiernan |first=Robert F. |title=Gore Vidal |publisher=Frederick Ungar Publishing, Inc.|date=1982|pages=94–100}}</ref> making the eponymous heroine a [[transsexual]] waging a "war against gender roles".<ref name="GLBTQ Humor">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/humor,2.html |title=Humor: Use of a Surrogate and Connecting Openly Gay and Lesbian Characters to a Larger Society |first=Arnie |last=Kantrowitz |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 4, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204065045/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/humor,2.html |archive-date=February 4, 2015 }}</ref><ref name="GLBTQ Vidal">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/vidal_g.html |title=Vidal, Gore (1925-2012) |first=Edmund |last=Miller |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 4, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114054008/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/vidal_g.html |archive-date=January 14, 2015 }}</ref>
In 1969, Taiwanese author [[Lin Hwai-min]] published "Cicada" in his short story collection of the same name, ''Cicada''. "Cicada" follows the lives of several college students living in [[Ximending]], Taipei, who explore and struggle with expressing homosexual desires for each other.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Moran |first=Thomas |title=The Columbia Companion to Modern East Asian Literature |date=2003 |publisher=Columbia University Press |editor-last=Mostow |editor-first=Joshua S. |pages=489–90 |chapter=SAME-SEX LOVE IN RECENT CHINESE LITERATURE |doi=10.7312/most11314 |jstor=10.7312/most11314 |isbn=978-0-231-50736-3 |s2cid=160298736 }}</ref>
Though [[Thomas Pynchon]]'s ''[[Gravity's Rainbow]]'' (1973) was unanimously recommended by the [[Pulitzer Prize]] fiction jury to receive the 1974 award, the Pulitzer board chose instead to make no award that year.<ref>{{cite web |last=McDowell |first=Edwin |date=May 11, 1984 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/11/books/publishing-pulitzer-controversies.html |title=Publishing: Pulitzer Controversies |work=The New York Times |page=C26}}</ref> In 2005 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' named the novel one of its "All-Time 100 Greatest Novels", a list of the best English language novels from 1923 to 2005.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.time.com/time/2005/100books/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051021140441/http://www.time.com/time/2005/100books/ |archive-date=October 21, 2005 |title=All-Time 100 Novels |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=October 16, 2005|access-date=February 6, 2015}}</ref> Other notable novels from the 1970s include [[Manuel Puig]]'s ''[[Kiss of the Spider Woman (novel)|Kiss of the Spider Woman]]'' (1976),<ref name="GLBTQ Puig">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/puig_m.html |title=Puig, Manuel (1932-1990) |first=Francisco |last=Soto |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207014540/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/puig_m.html |archive-date=February 7, 2015 }}</ref> [[Andrew Holleran]]'s ''[[Dancer from the Dance]]'' (1978),<ref name="GLBTQ Holleran">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/holleran_a.html |title=Holleran, Andrew (b. 1943?) |first=Gregory W. |last=Bredbeck |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207024622/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/holleran_a.html |archive-date=February 7, 2015 }}</ref> and ''[[Tales of the City (novel)|Tales of the City]]'' (1978), the first volume of [[Armistead Maupin]]'s long-running [[Tales of the City|''Tales of the City'' series]].<ref name="GLBTQ Humor"/>
In the 1980s, [[Edmund White]] — who had cowritten the 1977 gay [[sex manual]] ''[[The Joy of Gay Sex]]'' — published the semiautobiographical novels ''[[A Boy's Own Story]]'' (1982) and ''[[The Beautiful Room Is Empty]]'' (1988).<ref name="GLBTQ White">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/white_e.html |title=White, Edmund (b. 1940) |first=Randal |last=Woodland |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030130903/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/white_e.html |archive-date=October 30, 2014 }}</ref> [[Bret Easton Ellis]] also came to prominence with ''[[Less than Zero (novel)|Less than Zero]]'' (1985), ''[[The Rules of Attraction]]'' (1987) and later ''[[American Psycho]]'' (1991).<ref name="GLBTQ Ellis">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/ellis_be.html |title=Ellis, Bret Easton (b. 1964) |first=Steven |last=Cordova |publisher=glbtq.com |access-date=February 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206212350/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/ellis_be.html |archive-date=February 6, 2015 }}</ref> Nobel Prize winner [[Roger Martin du Gard]]'s unfinished ''Lieutenant-Colonel de Maumort'', written between 1941 and 1958, was published posthumously in 1983. It explores adolescent homosexual relations and includes a fictional first-person account, written in 1944, of a brief tragic encounter between a young soldier and a bakery apprentice in rural France.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pollard|first1=Patrick|title=André Gide: Homosexual Moralist|date=1991|publisher=Yale University Press|page=456n141|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6ZoHrfrjs1gC&pg=PA456|access-date=February 17, 2016|isbn=0-300-04998-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author-link=Roger Martin du Gard |first=Roger |last=Martin du Gard |title=Lieutenant-Colonel de Maumort |location=New York |publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf]] |date=1983 |chapter=VI (adolescence), XIII (encounter)}}</ref>
Colombian-born gay author [[Fernando Vallejo]] on 1994 published his semi-autobiographical novel [[Our Lady of the Assassins (novel)|''Our Lady of the Assassins'']]. The novel deals with the topic of homosexuality in a secondary way, but it is notable for being set in the context of a Latin American country where it is a taboo.
Taiwanese author [[Chu Tʽien-wen|Chu T'ien-wen]]'s ''[[Notes of a Desolate Man]]'' (1994) is written from the first-person perspective of a Taiwanese gay man. Chu compiled the experience of gay men in various cultures as portrayed through media to construct the narrative of ''Notes of a Desolate Man''. The novel has often been criticized by Taiwanese critics for its fragmentary structure and narrative, due to Chu's frequent use of quotations and references. Chu's "presumably heterosexual" and female identity has also inspired various different readings of the novel, as well as "a tension that has been used to serve very different sorts of sexual politics."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=CHANG |first=CHIH-WEI |date=2011 |title=Bringing out "Roland Barthes" from Chu T'ien-wen's "Notes of a Desolate Man (Huangren shouji)" |journal=Comparative Literature |volume=63 |issue=4 |page=425 |doi=10.1215/00104124-1444455 |jstor=41412148 |issn=0010-4124}}</ref>
The following year, [[Chi Ta-wei]] published ''Sensory World'' (1995), which is composed of short stories are significant because of their explicit discussion of sex, sexuality, gender, [[transgender]] identity, and male homosexual desire. In 1997, Chi published ''Queer Carnival'', which contains a detailed list of Taiwanese [[queer]] literature (covering themes of [[gay]], [[lesbian]], transgender, and other sexuality and gender identities).<ref>{{Cite book |last=Moran |first=Thomas |title=The Columbia Companion to Modern East Asian Literature |date=2003 |publisher=Columbia University Press |editor-last=Mostow |editor-first=Joshua S. |page=491 |chapter=SAME-SEX LOVE IN RECENT CHINESE LITERATURE |doi=10.7312/most11314 |jstor=10.7312/most11314 |isbn=978-0-231-50736-3 |s2cid=160298736 }}</ref>
In 1997, the short story "[[Brokeback Mountain (short story)|Brokeback Mountain]]" written by [[Annie Proulx]] was published.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.simonsays.com/content/book.cfm?tab=1&pid=517271 | title = Brokeback Mountain: Story to Screenplay (Trade Paperback) | publisher = [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]] | access-date = July 24, 2007 }}</ref> It would be later adapted into a [[Brokeback Mountain|critically acclaimed Academy Award nominated film]] in 2005.
The founding of the [[Lambda Literary Award]] in 1988 helped increase the visibility of LGBT literature.<ref name="Lambda">{{cite web |url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/lgbt/Lambda-Literary-Foundation-marks-25-years-of-LGBT-writers/42961.html |title=Lambda Literary Foundation marks 25 years of LGBT writers |work=[[Windy City Times]] |first=Charlsie |last=Dewey |date=May 28, 2013 |access-date=February 6, 2015}}</ref>
=== 21st century === [[File:Alan hollinghurst 2011.jpg|thumb|[[Alan Hollinghurst]] won the [[Booker Prize]] for his 2004 novel ''[[The Line of Beauty]]'', which features a young gay protagonist navigating 1980s Britain.]] In the 21st century, much of LGBT literature has achieved a high level of sophistication and many works have earned mainstream acclaim. Notable authors include [[Alan Hollinghurst]], [[Michael Cunningham]], [[Colm Tóibín]], [[John Boyne]], and [[Andrew Sean Greer]]. Greer, an openly gay man, won the 2018 [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] for ''[[Less (novel)|Less]]''. LGBT themes have also become more visible in a growing body of high-quality young adult literature, with notable authors including [[Alex Sánchez (author)|Alex Sánchez]], [[Stephen Chbosky]], [[Shyam Selvadurai]], [[Perry Moore]], [[Adam Silvera]], [[Benjamin Alire Sáenz]], and [[David Levithan]]. [[Becky Albertalli]]'s teen novel ''[[Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda]]'' was adapted into the feature film ''[[Love, Simon]]'' by [[20th Century Fox]], the first film by a major studio focused on a gay teenage romance.<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/10/31/love-simon-first-look/ |title=''Love, Simon'': Your first look at 2018's major studio gay teen romance |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |access-date=March 11, 2018 |last=Stack |first=Tim |archive-date=November 23, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123114541/https://ew.com/movies/2017/10/31/love-simon-first-look/ }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://variety.com/2018/scene/vpage/love-simon-premiere-gay-teen-romantic-comedy-1202722636/ |title=''Love, Simon'' Stars Say Gay Teen Romance Will Save Lives |last=Lang |first=Brent |date=March 9, 2018|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=March 11, 2018}}</ref> [[Casey McQuiston]]'s ''[[Red, White & Royal Blue]]'' is another example of young adult gay and bisexual romantic fiction, and there is currently in the works a film adaptation by [[Amazon Studios]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Red, White & Royal Blue |url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/41150487-red-white-royal-blue |website=[[Goodreads]] |access-date=27 November 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Mike Fleming Jr |date=10 April 2019 |title=Amazon Studios, Berlanti Productions Win Casey McQuiston Novel ''Red White & Royal Blue'' |url=https://deadline.com/2019/04/red-white-royal-blue-novel-amazon-studios-berlanti-productions-win-novel-auction-1202593251/ |access-date=27 November 2020 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]]}}</ref>
==Gay pulp== {{main|Gay male pulp fiction|Lesbian pulp fiction}} Gay pulp fiction or gay pulps, refers to printed works, primarily fiction, that include references to male [[homosexuality]], specifically male [[Gay sexual practices|gay sex]], and that are cheaply produced, typically in [[paperback book]]s made of wood pulp paper; lesbian pulp fiction is similar work about women. [[Michael Bronski]], the editor of an anthology of gay pulp writing, notes in his introduction, "Gay pulp is not an exact term, and it is used somewhat loosely to refer to a variety of books that had very different origins and markets"<ref>Bronski, Michael, ed. ''Pulp Friction: Uncovering the Golden Age of Gay Male Pulps''. New York: St. Martin's Griffin, 2003, page 2.</ref> People often use the term to refer to the "classic" gay pulps that were produced before about 1970, but it may also be used to refer to the gay erotica or pornography in [[paperback]] [[book]] or [[digest magazine]] form produced since that date.
==Speculative fiction== {{main|LGBT themes in speculative fiction|LGBT themes in horror fiction}} [[File:Carmilla.jpg|thumb|Illustration by [[D. H. Friston]] from the first publication of the [[lesbian vampire]] novella ''[[Carmilla]]'' (1872) by [[Sheridan Le Fanu]]<ref name="Garber"/><ref name="Carmilla 1"/><ref name="Carmilla 2"/>]] [[Homosexuality in speculative fiction]] refers to the incorporation of [[homosexual]] themes into [[science fiction]], [[fantasy]], [[horror fiction]] and related genres which together constitute [[speculative fiction]]. Such elements may include a [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]] or [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) character as the protagonist or a major character, or exploration of varieties of [[human sexual behavior|sexual experience]] that deviate from the conventional.
Science fiction and fantasy have traditionally been [[puritanical]] genres aimed at a male readership, and can be more restricted than non-genre literature by their [[genre convention|conventions]] of characterisation and the effect that these conventions have on depictions of sexuality and gender.<ref name="Clute">{{cite book |author-link=John Clute |author=Clute, John |author2=Peter Nicholls |title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction |location=London |publisher=[[Orbit Books]] |issue=1993 (2nd edition, 1999) |isbn=1-85723-897-4 |page=1088|author2-link=Peter Nicholls (writer) |title-link=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction |year=1999 }}</ref> During the [[pulp magazine]] era (1920s-1930s), explicit sexuality of any kind was rare in genre science fiction and fantasy.<ref name="Clute"/> Then, according to [[Joanna Russ]], in the more relaxed [[Golden Age of Science Fiction]] (1940s-1950s) the genre "resolutely ignored the whole subject" of homosexuality.<ref name="UW pg. xxii">{{cite book|author=Joanna Russ|chapter=Introduction |title=Uranian Worlds |page=xxii}}</ref> Some writers were able to introduce more explicit sexuality into their work as the readership for science fiction and fantasy began to age in the 1950s; however until the late 1960s few depicted alternative sexuality or revised gender roles, or openly investigated sexual questions.<ref name="Clute"/> After the pushing back of boundaries in the 1960s and 1970s, homosexuality gained much wider acceptance, and was often incorporated into otherwise conventional SF stories with little comment. By the 1980s, blatant homophobia was no longer considered acceptable to most readers.<ref name="Ency Homo">{{cite book|author=Dynes, Wayne R. |author2=Warren Johansson |author3=William A. Percy |author4=Stephen Donaldson |title=Encyclopedia of Homosexuality |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofho02onar |url-access=registration |chapter=Science Fiction |publisher=[[Garland Publishing]] |year=1990 |isbn=978-0-8240-6544-7 |page=[https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofho02onar/page/n727 752]}}</ref> In [[Lois McMaster Bujold]]'s ''[[Ethan of Athos]]'' (1986), the titular "unlikely hero" is gay obstetrician Dr. Ethan Urquhart, whose dangerous adventure alongside the first woman he has ever met presents both a future society where homosexuality is the norm and the lingering sexism and homophobia of our own world.<ref name="Buffalo">{{cite web |url=http://www.buffalolib.org/vufind/Record/1170198/Reviews |title=Reviews: ''Ethan of Athos'' |publisher=[[Buffalo & Erie County Public Library]] |access-date=September 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Tor Walton">{{cite web| url=http://www.tor.com/blogs/2009/04/quest-for-ovaries-lois-mcmaster-bujolds-ethan-of-athos |title=Quest for Ovaries: Lois McMaster Bujold's ''Ethan of Athos'' |first=Jo |last=Walton |author-link=Jo Walton |website=Tor.com |date=April 2, 2009 |access-date=September 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name="SF Site">{{cite web |url=https://www.sfsite.com/01a/ea335.htm |title=The SF Site Featured Review: ''Ethan of Athos'' |first=Nicki |last=Gerlach |publisher=[[SF Site]] |year=2011 |access-date=September 7, 2014}}</ref> ''Uranian Worlds'', by Eric Garber and Lyn Paleo, was compiled in 1983 and is an authoritative guide to science fiction literature featuring gay, lesbian, transgender, and related themes. The book covers science fiction literature published before 1990 (2nd edition, 1990), providing a short review and commentary on each piece.<ref name="UW">{{cite book |author=Garber & Paleo |title=Uranian Worlds |year=1983}}</ref><ref>Pearson, Hollinger & Groden, p.7</ref>
As speculative fiction gives authors and readers the freedom to imagine societies that are different from real-life cultures, this freedom makes speculative fiction a useful means of examining sexual bias by forcing the reader to reconsider his or her [[heteronormative]] cultural assumptions. It has also been claimed that LGBT readers identify strongly with the [[mutant (fiction)|mutants]], [[Extraterrestrials in fiction|aliens]] and other outsider characters found in speculative fiction.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Science fiction|others=Griffith, Nicola,, Pagel, Stephen|isbn=0-87951-856-1|edition=First|location=Woodstock, N.Y.|oclc=38216118|last1=Griffith|first1=Nicola|last2=Pagel|first2=Stephen|year=1998|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/sciencefiction0000unse}}</ref>
James Jenkins of [[Valancourt Books]] notes that the connection between gay fiction and horror goes back to the [[Gothic fiction|Gothic]] novels of the 1790s and early 1800s.<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> Many Gothic authors, like [[Matthew Lewis (writer)|Matthew Lewis]], [[William Thomas Beckford]] and [[Francis Lathom]], were homosexual, and according to Jenkins "the traditional explanation for the gay/horror connection is that it was impossible for them to write openly about gay themes back then (or even perhaps express them, since words like 'gay' and 'homosexual' didn't exist), so they sublimated them and expressed them in more acceptable forms, using the medium of a transgressive genre like horror fiction."<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> Early works with clear gay subtext include Lewis's ''[[The Monk]]'' (1796) and both [[Charles Maturin]]'s ''The Fatal Revenge'' (1807) and ''[[Melmoth the Wanderer]]'' (1820).<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> Somewhat later came the first [[lesbian vampire]] novella ''[[Carmilla]]'' (1872) by [[Sheridan Le Fanu]]<ref name="Garber"/><ref name="Carmilla 1"/><ref name="Carmilla 2"/> and ''[[The Picture of Dorian Gray]]'' (1890) by [[Oscar Wilde]], which shocked readers with its sensuality and overtly homosexual characters.<ref name="Garber & Paleo 1983 148"/> There is even gay subtext in [[Bram Stoker]]'s ''[[Dracula]]'' (1897) as the title character warns off the female vampires and claims Jonathan Harker, saying "This man belongs to me!"<ref name="HP 2014-05"/> The erotic metaphor of vampirism, inspired by ''Carmilla'', has resulted in numerous vampire films since the 1970s strongly implying or explicitly portraying lesbianism.<ref name=DR>{{cite book |title=Dark Romance: Sexuality in the Horror Film |last=Hogan |first=David J. |chapter=Lugosi, Lee, and the Vampires |pages=146–163|year=1997 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=0-7864-0474-4 }}</ref>
James R. Keller writes that in particular, "Gay and lesbian readers have been quick to identify with the representation of the vampire, suggesting its experiences parallel those of the sexual outsider."<ref name="Keller 12-14">{{cite book |title=Anne Rice and Sexual Politics: The Early Novels |first=James R. |last=Keller |publisher=McFarland |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-7864-0846-7 |pages=12–14 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zM7tFSNAiXUC&q=anne+rice+homoerotic&pg=PA12}}</ref> [[Richard Dyer]] discusses the recurring homoerotic motifs of vampire fiction in his article "Children of the Night", primarily "the necessity of secrecy, the persistence of a forbidden passion, and the fear of discovery."<ref name="Keller 12-14"/><ref name="Dyer">{{cite book |first=Richard |last=Dyer |chapter=Children of the Night: Vampirism as Homosexuality, Homosexuality as Vampirism |title=Sweet Dreams: Sexuality, Gender, and Popular Fiction |editor=Susannah Radstone |location=London |publisher=Lawrence & Wishart Ltd. |year=1988 |page=64}}</ref> With the vampire having been a recurring metaphor for same-sex desire from before Stoker's ''Dracula'', Dyer observes that historically earlier representations of vampires tend to evoke horror and later ones turn that horror into celebration.<ref name="Keller 12-14"/><ref name="Dyer"/> The homoerotic overtones of [[Anne Rice]]'s celebrated ''[[The Vampire Chronicles]]'' series (1976–present) are well documented,<ref name="Keller 12-14"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/1996/09/16/questions_5/ |title=Submit to Anne |website=Salon.com |date=September 16, 1996 |access-date=June 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/11/movies/film-review-interview-with-the-vampire-rapture-and-terror-bound-by-blood.html |title=Film Review: ''Interview with the Vampire''; Rapture and Terror, Bound by Blood |first=Janet |last=Maslin |date=November 11, 1994 |website=The New York Times |access-date=June 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/13/movies/in-search-of-the-man-within-the-monster.html |title=In Search of the Man Within the Monster |first=Caryn |last=James |date=November 13, 1994 |website=The New York Times |access-date=June 25, 2014}}</ref> and its publication reinforced the "widely recognized parallel between the queer and the vampire."<ref name="Keller 12-14"/>
==Comics== {{main|LGBT themes in comics|Bara (genre)|Yuri (genre)|Yaoi}} LGBT themes in comics is a relatively new concept, as [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]] and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) themes and characters were historically omitted intentionally from the content of [[comic book]]s and their [[comic strip]] predecessors, due to either censorship or the perception that comics were for children.<ref>''[[The Yellow Kid]]'', first serialized in 1895, is considered the "first newspaper comic strip", though "the mechanics of comic strips were in use well before the ''Kid''{{'s}} debut in illustrated magazines." {{citation|last=Wood|first=Mary|title=Origins of the Kid|url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~MA04/wood/ykid/illustrated.htm|publisher=xroads.virginia.edu|date=February 2, 2004|access-date=March 18, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180302114128/http://xroads.virginia.edu/~ma04/wood/ykid/illustrated.htm|archive-date=March 2, 2018}}</ref> With any mention of [[homosexuality]] in mainstream United States comics forbidden by the [[Comics Code Authority]] (CCA) until 1989,<ref name="Nyberg 1998">{{citation |last=Nyberg |first=Amy Kiste |title=Seal of Approval: The History of the Comics Code |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year=1998 |location=Jackson |pages=143, 175–176 |isbn=0-87805-975-X }}</ref> earlier attempts at exploring these issues in the US took the form of subtle hints or [[subtext]] regarding a character's sexual orientation.<ref name="Applegate">{{citation|last=Applegate |first=David |title=''Coming Out in the Comic Strips'' |url=http://cagle.msnbc.com/hogan/features/out/out.asp |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |access-date=March 29, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002083335/http://cagle.msnbc.com/hogan/features/out/out.asp |archive-date=October 2, 2008 }}</ref> LGBT themes were tackled earlier in [[underground comics]] from the early 1970s onward. Independently published one-off comic books and series, often produced by gay creators and featuring autobiographical storylines, tackled political issues of interest to LGBT readers.
Comic strips have also dealt in subtext and innuendo, their wide distribution in newspapers limiting their inclusion of controversial material. The first openly gay characters appeared in prominent strips in the late 1970s; representation of LGBT issues in these titles causes vociferous reaction, both praise and condemnation, to the present day. Comic strips aimed at LGBT audiences are also syndicated in gay- and lesbian-targeted magazines and comics have been created to educate people about LGBT-related issues and to influence real-world politics, with their format and distribution allowing them to transmit messages more subtle, complex, and positive than typical education material. Portrayal of LGBT themes in comics is recognized by several notable awards, including the [[Gaylactic Spectrum Award]] and [[GLAAD Media Awards]] for outstanding comic book and comic strip.
Since the 1990s, LGBT themes have become more common in mainstream US comics, including in a number of titles in which a gay character is the star. European comics have been more inclusive from an earlier date. The lack of censorship, and greater acceptance of comics as a medium of adult entertainment led to less controversy about the representation of LGBT characters. The popular Japanese [[manga]] tradition has included genres of girls' comics that feature homosexual relationships since the 1970s, in the form of ''[[yaoi]]'' and ''[[yuri (genre)|yuri]]''. These works are often extremely romantic and include archetypal characters that often are not identified as gay. Since the Japanese "gay boom" of the 1990s, a body of manga aimed at LGBT customers has been produced, which have more realistic and autobiographical themes. [[Hentai|Pornographic manga]] also often includes sexualised depictions of lesbians and intersex people. [[Queer theory|Queer theorists]]{{who|date=October 2011}} have noted that LGBT characters in mainstream comic books are usually shown as assimilated into heterosexual society, whereas in alternative comics the diversity and uniqueness of LGBT culture is emphasized.
==Children's fiction== ===Gay themes=== Compared to [[Gay (male) teen fiction|gay]] and [[lesbian teen fiction]], sales of gay-themed books for younger children, and availability of these books in public and school libraries, remain "very dicey and very different".<ref name="Getlin">{{cite news |last=Getlin |first=Josh |title=Gay references touchy in children's literature |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=January 5, 2004 |url=http://www.abffe.org/bbw-babies.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724215227/http://www.abffe.org/bbw-babies.htm |archive-date=July 24, 2011 |access-date=March 6, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Spence |first=Alex |title=Controversial Books in the Public Library: A Comparative Survey of Holdings of Gay-Related Children's Picture Books |journal=[[The Library Quarterly]] |issue=3 |volume=70 |date=July 2000 |pages=335–379 |doi=10.1086/603196|s2cid=140739803 }}</ref>
''[[When Megan Went Away]]'' (1979) was the first picture book to include LGBT characters.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Naidoo |first1=Jaimie Campbell |title=Rainbow family collections: Selecting and using children's books with lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer content |date=2012 |publisher=Libraries Unlimited |location=Santa Barbara, CA |isbn=978-1-59884-960-8|pages=xiv, 40, 49}}</ref> The story, written by [[Jane Severance]] and illustrated by Tea Schook, concerns a preteen girl whose lesbian mother and her partner have separated.<ref name="crisp">{{cite journal |last1=Crisp |first1=Thomas |title=Setting the record 'straight': An interview with Jane Severance |journal=[[Children's Literature Association Quarterly]] |date=2010 |volume=35 |issue=1 |pages=87–96 |doi=10.1353/chq.0.1950 |s2cid=144164146 }}</ref> The first children's book with gay male characters was ''[[Jenny Lives with Eric and Martin]]''.{{sfn|Naidoo|2012|p=49}} Originally published in 1981 in Danish as ''Mette bor hos Morten og Erik'', it tells the story of Jenny, her father and his partner and their daily life. Controversy and politicization followed its publication.
Some of the best known children's books with gay themes include ''[[Heather Has Two Mommies]]'' (1989) and ''[[Daddy's Roommate]]'' (1991), published by [[LGBT]] publisher [[Alyson Books]]. Both books discussed same-sex parenting and attracted criticism and controversy. The [[American Library Association]] ranked ''Heather Has Two Mommies'' as the third and second most frequently [[List of most commonly-challenged books in the United States|challenged book]] in the United States in 1993 and 1994, respectively.
Recent controversies include ''[[King & King]]'', originally written in Dutch and published in English in 2002. The book is about a prince uninterested in princesses, who eventually falls in love with another prince. In 2006, parents sued a Massachusetts school district after a teacher read the book to their son's second grade class.<ref name="Meade">{{cite news|last=Meade |first=Michael J. |title=Parents File Federal Suit Over Gay Book |publisher=365Gay.com |date=April 27, 2006 |url=http://www.365gay.com/Newscon06/04/042706book.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080607045941/http://365gay.com/Newscon06/04/042706book.htm |archive-date=June 7, 2008 |access-date=March 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Williams">{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Margo |title=New Dispute Over Gay Books Erupts At Mass. School |publisher=365Gay.com|date=April 20, 2006 |url=http://365gay.com/Newscon06/04/042006book.htm |access-date=March 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061028234617/http://365gay.com/Newscon06/04/042006book.htm |archive-date=October 28, 2006}}</ref> ''[[And Tango Makes Three]]'' (2005) by [[Justin Richardson]] and [[Peter Parnell]] has been frequently challenged, and is often on the American Library Associations's List of Challenged Books for Banned Books Week.<ref name="Tango Banned">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nypl.org/blog/2013/09/23/banned-books-week-and-tango-makes-three|title=Banned Books Week: ''And Tango Makes Three''|website=The New York Public Library|access-date=December 10, 2017}}</ref> It was ranked ninth on this list in 2017.<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yyd2kII-8D4 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/yyd2kII-8D4 |archive-date=December 13, 2021 |url-status=live|title=Top 10 Most Challenged Books of 2017|publisher=Banned Books Week|date=April 9, 2018|via=[[YouTube]]|access-date=September 13, 2018}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The book tells the true story of two male penguins who adopt an egg and raise the baby once it has hatched. While it has been banned<ref name="Tango Banned"/> and debated<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/11532897/Gay-penguins-have-no-place-in-our-libraries-say-parents.html|title=Gay penguins have no place in our libraries, say parents|journal=Daily Telegraph|last=Brown|first=Kat|date=April 13, 2015|access-date=December 10, 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> many times, it has been awarded and noted by the American Library Association on their Rainbow Book List.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/awardsgrants/rainbow-project-book-list|title=Rainbow Project Book List {{!}} Awards & Grants|website=www.ala.org|language=en|access-date=December 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/awardsgrants/content/and-tango-makes-three-0|title=And Tango Makes Three {{!}} Awards & Grants|website=www.ala.org|language=en|access-date=December 10, 2017}}</ref>
In 2018, [[Little Bee Books]] partnered with media advocacy group [[GLAAD]] for a series of books that offered positive LGBT representation in children's literature. The partnership kicked off with ''[[Prince & Knight]]'', written by Daniel Haack and illustrated by Stevie Lewis, which was named to the American Library Association's Rainbow Book List and was named a best book of the year by ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'', [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] and the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thewrap.com/glaad-to-publish-lgbtq-childrens-book-series-starting-with-prince-knight-exclusive/|title=GLAAD to Publish LGBTQ Book Series for Children|date=May 17, 2018|website=TheWrap|language=en-US|access-date=September 4, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.danielhaack.com/books|title=Daniel Haack — Books|website=Daniel Haack|language=en-US|access-date=September 4, 2019}}</ref> The partnership has gone on to include books that also offer lesbian, transgender and gender non-conforming representation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/maiden-and-princess-childrens-book_n_5b927e93e4b0cf7b003f1754|title=In 'Maiden & Princess,' Two Young Women Find Their Happily Ever After|last=Wong|first=Curtis M.|date=September 7, 2018|website=HuffPost|language=en|access-date=September 4, 2019}}</ref>
Australian titles include the books in the 'Learn to Include' series: ''[[The Rainbow Cubby House]]'', ''My House'', ''Going to Fair Day'' and ''Koalas on Parade''. ''[[House of Hades]]'' (2013), Book 4 in the young adult series ''[[The Heroes of Olympus]]'' by [[Rick Riordan]], features a gay supporting character, Nico di Angelo.
A more extensive list of gay children's literature includes:<ref>{{cite web|last=Ann |first=Frances |url=http://sfpl.org/index.php?pg=2000154901 |title=A Rainbow Celebration: Gays & Lesbians in Books for Children |publisher=San Francisco Public Library |access-date=June 29, 2014}}</ref>{{div col|colwidth=25em;}} * ''A Name on the Quilt: A Story of Remembrance'' by Jeannine Atkins * ''Uncle Bobby's Wedding'' by Sarah S. In July 2014, Singapore's National Library Board (NLB), a state-funded network of 26 public libraries, confirmed it would destroy three children's books with pro-LGBT families themes for being "against its 'pro-family' stance[,] following complaints by a parent and its own internal review". The decision was widely criticized by LGBT supporters and the arts and literary community who see the actions as akin to [[book burning]]s and other forms of [[censorship]]. The three books are ''And Tango Makes Three'', which covers the true story of a pair of male penguins that successfully raise a chick, ''The White Swan Express'', which features children adopted by a variety of families including gay, mixed-race and single parents, and ''Who's in My Family'', which references families with homosexual parents. Two weeks after a gay rights rally, these books "sparked a fierce debate" between the religious conservatives, who opposed the rally, and Singapore's growing gay-rights lobby.<ref name=ref1>{{cite web |title=Singapore national library to destroy LGBT-themed children's books |date=July 11, 2014 |publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]] |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/singapore-destroy-books-1565594-Jul2014/ |access-date=March 6, 2015}}</ref>
